TRANSLATOR ’S PREFACE To arrive at a just estimate of [a renowned man]276-a renowned man ’s character one must judge it by the standards of [his]276-a renowned man time , not [ours]277-we . Judged by the standards of one century , [the noblest characters of an earlier one]278-the noblest characters of an earlier one lose much of [their]278-the noblest characters of an earlier one luster ; judged by the standards of to - day , there is probably [no illustrious man of four or five centuries ago whose character could meet the test at all points]279-no illustrious man of four or five centuries ago whose character could meet the test at all points . But the character of [Joan of Arc]110-joan is unique . It can be measured by the standards of all times without misgiving or apprehension as to the result . Judged by any of [them]280-them , it is still flawless , it is still ideally perfect ; it still occupies the loftiest place possible to human attainment , a loftier one than has been reached by [any other mere mortal]281-any other mere mortal . When [we]277-we reflect that [her]110-joan century was the brutalest , the wickedest , the rottenest in history since the darkest ages , [we]277-we are lost in wonder at the miracle of such a product from such a soil . The contrast between [her]110-joan and [her]110-joan century is the contrast between day and night . [She]110-joan was truthful when lying was the common speech of [men]282-men ; [she]110-joan was honest when honesty was become a lost virtue ; [she]110-joan was [a keeper of promises when the keeping of a promise]283-a keeper of promises when the keeping of a promise was expected of [no one]284-no one ; [she]110-joan gave [her]110-joan great mind to great thoughts and great purposes when other great minds wasted themselves upon pretty fancies or upon poor ambitions ; [she]110-joan was modest , and fine , and delicate when to be loud and coarse might be said to be universal ; [she]110-joan was full of pity when a merciless cruelty was the rule ; [she]110-joan was steadfast when stability was unknown , and honorable in an age which had forgotten what honor was ; [she]110-joan was [a rock of convictions]285-a rock of convictions in a time when [men]282-men believed in nothing and scoffed at all things ; [she]110-joan was unfailingly true to an age that was false to the core ; [she]110-joan maintained [her]110-joan personal dignity unimpaired in an age of fawnings and servilities ; [she]110-joan was of a dauntless courage when hope and courage had perished in the hearts of [[her]110-joan nation]287-her nation ; [she]110-joan was spotlessly pure in mind and body when society in the highest places was foul in both — [she]110-joan was all these things in an age when crime was the common business of [lords]288-lords and [princes]289-princes , and when [the highest personages in [Christendom]21-christendom]290-the highest personages in christendom were able to astonish even that infamous era and make [it]291-it stand aghast at the spectacle of [their]290-the highest personages in christendom atrocious lives black with unimaginable treacheries , butcheries , and beastialities . [She]110-joan was perhaps [the only entirely unselfish person whose name has a place in profane history]292-the only entirely unselfish person whose name has a place in profane history . No vestige or suggestion of self - seeking can be found in any word or deed of [hers]110-joan . When [she]110-joan had rescued [[her]110-joan King]293-her king from [his]293-her king vagabondage , and set [his]293-her king crown upon [his]293-her king head , [she]110-joan was offered rewards and honors , but [she]110-joan refused them all , and would take nothing . All [she]110-joan would take for [herself]110-joan — if [the King]270-the king would grant it — was leave to go back to [[her]110-joan village home]295-her village home , and tend [her]110-joan sheep again , and feel [[her]110-joan mother]296-her mother ’s arms about [her]110-joan , and be [[her]110-joan housemaid]297-her housemaid and [helper]298-helper . The selfishness of [this unspoiled general of victorious armies]299-this unspoiled general of victorious armies , companion of [princes]289-princes , and idol of [an applauding and grateful nation]301-an applauding and grateful nation , reached but that far and no farther . The work wrought by [Joan of Arc]110-joan may fairly be regarded as ranking any recorded in history , when one considers the conditions under which it was undertaken , the obstacles in the way , and the means at [her]110-joan disposal . [Caesar]125-caesar carried conquests far , but [he]125-caesar did it with [the trained and confident veterans of [Rome]22-rome]302-the trained and confident veterans of rome , and was [a trained soldier]303-a trained soldier [himself]125-caesar ; and [Napoleon]126-napoleon swept away [the disciplined armies of [Europe]23-europe]304-the disciplined armies of europe , but [he]126-napoleon also was [a trained soldier]303-a trained soldier , and [he]126-napoleon began [his]126-napoleon work with [patriot battalions]306-patriot battalions inflamed and inspired by the miracle - working new breath of Liberty breathed upon [them]306-patriot battalions by the Revolution — [eager young apprentices to the splendid trade of war]307-eager young apprentices to the splendid trade of war , not [old and broken men - at - arms , despairing survivors of an age - long accumulation of monotonous defeats]308-old and broken men - at - arms , despairing survivors of an age - long accumulation of monotonous defeats ; but [Joan of Arc]110-joan , [a mere child in years]309-a mere child in years , ignorant , unlettered , [a poor village girl unknown and without influence]310-a poor village girl unknown and without influence , found [a great nation]311-a great nation lying in chains , helpless and hopeless under an alien domination , [its]311-a great nation treasury bankrupt , [its soldiers]312-its soldiers disheartened and dispersed , all spirit torpid , all courage dead in the hearts of [the people]313-the people through long years of foreign and domestic outrage and oppression , [[their]313-the people King]314-their king cowed , resigned to [its]311-a great nation fate , and preparing to fly [the country]315-the country ; and [she]110-joan laid [her]110-joan hand upon [this nation]316-this nation , this corpse , and it rose and followed [her]110-joan . [She]110-joan led [it]316-this nation from victory to victory , [she]110-joan turned back the tide of the Hundred Years ’ War , [she]110-joan fatally crippled the English power , and died with the earned title of DELIVERER OF [FRANCE]4-france , which [she]110-joan bears to this day . And for all reward , [the French King]317-the french king , whom [she]110-joan had crowned , stood supine and indifferent , while [French priests]318-french priests took [the noble child]319-the noble child , the most innocent , the most lovely , the most adorable the ages have produced , and burned [her]319-the noble child alive at the stake . A PECULIARITY OF [JOAN OF ARC ’S HISTORY]110-joan The details of the life of [Joan of Arc]110-joan form a biography which is unique among [the world]320-the world ’s biographies in one respect : It is the only story of a human life which comes to [us]321-us under oath , the only one which comes to [us]321-us from [the witness - stand]322-the witness - stand . The official records of the Great Trial of 1431 , and of the Process of Rehabilitation of a quarter of a century later , are still preserved in [the National Archives of [France]4-france]274-the national archives of france , and they furnish with remarkable fullness the facts of [her]110-joan life . The history of no other life of that remote time is known with either the certainty or the comprehensiveness that attaches to [hers]110-joan . [The Sieur Louis de Conte]110-joan is faithful to [her]110-joan official history in [his]317-the french king Personal Recollections , and thus far [his]317-the french king trustworthiness is unimpeachable ; but [his]317-the french king mass of added particulars must depend for credit upon [his]317-the french king word alone . [THE TRANSLATOR]324-the translator . [THE SIEUR LOUIS DE CONTE]110-joan To [[his]317-the french king Great - Great - Grand Nephews and [Nieces]325-nieces]127-his great - great - grand nephews and nieces This is the year 1492 . [I]0-i am eighty - two years of age . The things [I]0-i am going to tell [you]326-you are things which [I]0-i saw [myself]0-i as [a child]327-a child and as [a youth]328-a youth . In all the tales and songs and histories of [Joan of Arc]110-joan , which [you]326-you and [the rest of [the world]320-the world]329-the rest of the world read and sing and study in the books wrought in the late invented art of printing , mention is made of [me]0-i , [the Sieur Louis de Conte]110-joan — [I]0-i was [[her]110-joan page]331-her page and [secretary]332-secretary , [I]0-i was with [her]110-joan from the beginning until the end . [I]0-i was reared in [the same village]333-the same village with [her]110-joan . [I]0-i played with [her]110-joan every day , when [we]334-we were [little children]335-little children together , just as [you]326-you play with [[your]326-you mates]336-your mates . Now that [we]334-we perceive how great [she]110-joan was , now that [her]110-joan name fills [the whole world]337-the whole world , it seems strange that what [I]0-i am saying is true ; for it is as if a perishable paltry candle should speak of the eternal sun riding in the heavens and say , “ [He]2322-he was gossip and housemate to [me]0-i when [we]334-we were candles together . ”[0-i] And yet it is true , just as [I]0-i say . [I]0-i was [[her]110-joan playmate]338-her playmate , and [I]0-i fought at [her]110-joan side in the wars ; to this day [I]0-i carry in [my]0-i mind , fine and clear , the picture of that dear little figure , with breast bent to the flying horse ’s neck , charging at the head of [the armies of [France]4-france]339-the armies of france , [her]110-joan hair streaming back , [her]110-joan silver mail plowing steadily deeper and deeper into the thick of the battle , sometimes nearly drowned from sight by tossing heads of horses , uplifted sword - arms , wind - blow plumes , and intercepting shields . [I]0-i was with [her]110-joan to the end ; and when that black day came whose accusing shadow will lie always upon the memory of [the mitered French slaves of [England]24-england who were [[her]110-joan assassins]341-her assassins]340-the mitered french slaves of england who were her assassins , and upon [France]4-france [who stood idle and essayed no rescue]342-who stood idle and essayed no rescue , [my]0-i hand was the last [she]110-joan touched in life . As the years and the decades drifted by , and the spectacle of [the marvelous child]343-the marvelous child ’s meteor flight across [the war firmament of [France]4-france]344-the war firmament of france and its extinction in the smoke - clouds of the stake receded deeper and deeper into the past and grew ever more strange , and wonderful , and divine , and pathetic , [I]0-i came to comprehend and recognize [her]110-joan at last for what [she]110-joan was — the most noble life that was ever born into [this world]345-this world save only One . BOOK [I]0-i IN [DOMREMY]1-domremy Chapter 1 When Wolves Ran Free in [Paris]2-paris [I]0-i , [THE SIEUR LOUIS DE CONTE]110-joan , was born in [Neufchateau]25-neufchateau , on the 6th of January , 1410 ; that is to say , exactly two years before [Joan of Arc]110-joan was born in [Domremy]1-domremy . [[My]0-i family]346-my family had fled to [those distant regions from [the neighborhood of [Paris]2-paris]348-the neighborhood of paris in the first years of the century]347-those distant regions from the neighborhood of paris in the first years of the century . In politics [they]346-my family were [Armagnacs]349-armagnacs — [patriots]350-patriots ; [they]346-my family were for [[our]351-our own French King]352-our own french king , crazy and impotent as [he]352-our own french king was . [The Burgundian party]353-the burgundian party , who were for [the English]128-the english , had stripped [them]346-my family , and done it well . [They]346-my family took everything but [[[my]0-i father]354-my father ’s small nobility]355-my father ’s small nobility , and when [he]354-my father reached [Neufchateau]25-neufchateau [he]354-my father reached it in poverty and with a broken spirit . But the political atmosphere there was the sort [he]354-my father liked , and that was something . [He]354-my father came to [a region of comparative quiet]356-a region of comparative quiet ; [he]354-my father left behind [him]354-my father [a region peopled with furies , [madmen , devils]358-madmen , devils , where slaughter was a daily pastime and [no man]359-no man ’s life safe for a moment]357-a region peopled with furies , madmen , devils , where slaughter was a daily pastime and no man ’s life safe for a moment . In [Paris]2-paris , [mobs]360-mobs roared through [the streets]361-the streets nightly , sacking , burning , killing , unmolested , uninterrupted . The sun rose upon [wrecked and smoking buildings]362-wrecked and smoking buildings , and upon mutilated corpses lying here , there , and yonder about [the streets]361-the streets , just as [they]346-my family fell , and stripped naked by [thieves]364-thieves , [the unholy gleaners]365-the unholy gleaners after [the mob]366-the mob . [None]367-none had the courage to gather these dead for burial ; [they]346-my family were left there to rot and create plagues . And plagues [they]346-my family did create . Epidemics swept away [the people]313-the people like flies , and the burials were conducted secretly and by night , for public funerals were not allowed , lest the revelation of the magnitude of the plague ’s work unman [the people]313-the people and plunge [them]313-the people into despair . Then came , finally , the bitterest winter which had visited [France]4-france in five hundred years . Famine , pestilence , slaughter , ice , snow — [Paris]2-paris had all these at once . [The dead]370-the dead lay in heaps about [the streets]361-the streets , and wolves entered [the city]372-the city in daylight and devoured [them]370-the dead . Ah , [France]4-france had fallen low — so low ! For more than three quarters of a century [the English fangs]373-the english fangs had been bedded in [her]4-france flesh , and so cowed had [her]4-france armies become by ceaseless rout and defeat that it was said and accepted that the mere sight of [an English army]374-an english army was sufficient to put [a French one]375-a french one to flight . When [I]0-i was five years old the prodigious disaster of [Agincourt]26-agincourt fell upon [France]4-france ; and although [the English King]376-the english king went [home]377-home to enjoy [his]376-the english king glory , [he]376-the english king left [the country]315-the country prostrate and a prey to [roving bands of [Free Companions]380-free companions in the service of [the Burgundian party]353-the burgundian party]379-roving bands of free companions in the service of the burgundian party , and [one of [these bands]383-these bands]382-one of these bands came raiding through [Neufchateau]25-neufchateau one night , and by the light of [our]384-our burning roof - thatch [I]0-i saw all that were dear to [me]0-i in [this world]345-this world ( save [an elder brother]386-an elder brother , [[your]387-your ancestor]388-your ancestor , left behind with [the court]389-the court ) butchered while [they]390-they begged for mercy , and heard [the butchers]391-the butchers laugh at [their]391-the butchers prayers and mimic [their]391-the butchers pleadings . [I]0-i was overlooked , and escaped without hurt . When [the savages]392-the savages were gone [I]0-i crept out and cried the night away watching [the burning houses]393-the burning houses ; and [I]0-i was all alone , except for [the company of the dead]394-the company of the dead and [the wounded]395-the wounded , for the rest had taken flight and hidden [themselves]396-themselves . [I]0-i was sent to [Domremy]1-domremy , to [the priest , whose housekeeper]397-the priest , whose housekeeper became [a loving mother to [me]0-i]398-a loving mother to me . [The priest]399-the priest , in the course of time , taught [me]0-i to read and write , and [he]399-the priest and [I]0-i were [the only persons in [the village]401-the village who possessed this learning . At the time that [the house of [this good priest]403-this good priest , [Guillaume Fronte]129-pere fronte]402-the house of this good priest , guillaume fronte]400-the only persons in the village who possessed this learning . at the time that the house of this good priest , guillaume fronte , became [[my]0-i home]404-my home , [I]0-i was six years old . [We]405-we lived close by [the village church]406-the village church , and [the small garden of [[Joan]110-joan ’s parents]408-joan ’s parents]407-the small garden of joan ’s parents was behind [the church]409-the church . As to [that family]410-that family there were [Jacques]130-jacques d’Arc [the father]411-the father , [[his]130-jacques wife]412-his wife [Isabel Romee]131-isabel romee ; [three sons]413-three sons — [Jacques]130-jacques , ten years old , [Pierre]132-pierre , eight , and [Jean]115-jeanne , seven ; [Joan]110-joan , four , and [[her]110-joan baby sister]414-her baby sister [Catherine]133-catherine , about a year old . [I]0-i had [these children]415-these children for [playmates]416-playmates from the beginning . [I]0-i had [some other playmates]417-some other playmates besides — particularly [four boys]418-four boys : [Pierre Morel]132-pierre , [Etienne Roze]134-etienne roze , [Noel Rainguesson]135-noel , and [Edmond Aubrey]136-edmond aubrey , whose father was [maire at that time]419-maire at that time ; also [two girls , about [Joan]110-joan ’s age , who by and by became [her]110-joan favorites]420-two girls , about joan ’s age , who by and by became her favorites ; one was named [Haumetter]137-haumetter , the other was called [Little Mengette]138-little mengette . [These girls]421-these girls were [common peasant children]422-common peasant children , like [Joan]110-joan [herself]110-joan . When [they]421-these girls grew up , both married [common laborers]423-common laborers . [[Their]421-these girls estate]424-their estate was lowly enough , [you]425-you see ; yet a time came , many years after , when [no passing stranger]426-no passing stranger , howsoever great [he]426-no passing stranger might be , failed to go and pay [his]426-no passing stranger reverence to [those two humble old women who had been honored in [their]421-these girls youth by the friendship of [Joan of Arc]110-joan]427-those two humble old women who had been honored in their youth by the friendship of joan of arc . [These]421-these girls were [all good children , just of the ordinary peasant type]428-all good children , just of the ordinary peasant type ; not bright , of course — [you]425-you would not expect that — but good - hearted and companionable , obedient to [[their]421-these girls parents]429-their parents and [the priest]399-the priest ; and as [they]421-these girls grew up [they]421-these girls became properly stocked with narrowness and prejudices got at second hand from [[their]421-these girls elders]431-their elders , and adopted without reserve ; and without examination also — which goes without saying . [Their]421-these girls religion was inherited , [their]421-these girls politics the same . [John Huss]139-john huss and [[his]139-john huss sort]432-his sort might find fault with [the Church]409-the church , in [Domremy]1-domremy it disturbed [nobody]434-nobody ’s faith ; and when the split came , when [I]0-i was fourteen , and [we]435-we had [three Popes]436-three popes at once , [nobody in [Domremy]1-domremy]437-nobody in domremy was worried about how to choose among [them]436-three popes — [the Pope of [Rome]22-rome]438-the pope of rome was [the right one]439-the right one , [a Pope outside of [Rome]22-rome]440-a pope outside of rome was [no Pope]441-no pope at all . [Every human creature in [the village]401-the village]442-every human creature in the village was [an Armagnac]444-an armagnac — [a patriot]445-a patriot — and if [[we]435-we children]446-we children hotly hated nothing else in [the world]320-the world , [we]435-we did certainly hate the English and Burgundian name and polity in that way . Chapter 2 The Fairy Tree of [Domremy]1-domremy [[OUR]435-we [DOMREMY]1-domremy]1-domremy was like [any other humble little hamlet of that remote time and region]448-any other humble little hamlet of that remote time and region . [It]1-domremy was a maze of [crooked , narrow lanes]449-crooked , narrow lanes and alleys shaded and sheltered by the overhanging thatch roofs of [the barnlike houses]450-the barnlike houses . [The houses]451-the houses were dimly lighted by wooden - shuttered windows — that is , holes in the walls which served for windows . The floors were dirt , and there was very little furniture . Sheep and cattle grazing was the main industry ; [all the young folks]452-all the young folks tended flocks . The situation was beautiful . From one edge of [the village]401-the village a flowery plain extended in a wide sweep to [the river]454-the river — [the Meuse]28-the meuse ; from the rear edge of [the village]401-the village a grassy slope rose gradually , and at the top was the great oak forest — a forest that was deep and gloomy and dense , and full of interest for [[us]435-we children]456-us children , for many murders had been done in [it]1-domremy by [outlaws]457-outlaws in old times , and in still earlier times prodigious dragons that spouted fire and poisonous vapors from [their]458-their nostrils had [[their]458-their homes in [there]460-there]459-their homes in there . In fact , [one]461-one was still living in [there]460-there in [our]435-we own time . It was as long as a tree , and had a body as big around as a tierce , and scales like overlapping great tiles , and deep ruby eyes as large as [a cavalier]463-a cavalier ’s hat , and an anchor - fluke on its tail as big as [I]0-i do n’t know what , but very big , even unusually so for a dragon , as [everybody]464-everybody said who knew about dragons . It was thought that this dragon was of a brilliant blue color , with gold mottlings , but [no one]284-no one had ever seen it , therefore this was not known to be so , it was only an opinion . It was not [my]0-i opinion ; [I]0-i think there is no sense in forming an opinion when there is no evidence to form it on . If [you]466-you build [a person]467-a person without any bones in [him]467-a person [he]467-a person may look fair enough to the eye , but [he]467-a person will be limber and can not stand up ; and [I]0-i consider that evidence is the bones of an opinion . But [I]0-i will take up this matter more at large at another time , and try to make the justness of [my]0-i position appear . As to that dragon , [I]0-i always held the belief that its color was gold and without blue , for that has always been the color of dragons . That this dragon lay but a little way within [the wood]468-the wood at one time is shown by the fact that [Pierre Morel]132-pierre was in [there]460-there one day and smelt it , and recognized [it]470-it by the smell . It gives [one]461-one a horrid idea of how near to [us]472-us the deadliest danger can be and [we]472-us not suspect it . In the earliest times [a hundred knights from many remote places in [the earth]474-the earth]473-a hundred knights from many remote places in the earth would have gone in [there]460-there one after another , to kill the dragon and get the reward , but in [our]472-us time that method had gone out , and [the priest]399-the priest had become [the one that abolished dragons]477-the one that abolished dragons . [Pere Guillaume Fronte]129-pere fronte did it in this case . [He]129-pere fronte had a procession , with candles and incense and banners , and marched around the edge of the wood and exorcised the dragon , and it was never heard of again , although it was the opinion of [many that the smell never wholly passed away]478-many that the smell never wholly passed away . Not that any had ever smelt the smell again , for none had ; it was only an opinion , like that other — and lacked bones , [you]479-you see . [I]0-i know that the creature was there before the exorcism , but whether it was there afterward or not is a thing which [I]0-i can not be so positive about . In [a noble open space carpeted with grass on [the high ground]481-the high ground toward [Vaucouleurs]29-vaucouleurs]480-a noble open space carpeted with grass on the high ground toward vaucouleurs stood a most majestic beech tree with wide - reaching arms and a grand spread of shade , and by [it]460-there [a limpid spring of cold water]482-a limpid spring of cold water ; and on summer days [the children]483-the children went [there]460-there — oh , every summer for more than five hundred years — went [there]460-there and sang and danced around the tree for hours together , refreshing [themselves]483-the children at the spring from time to time , and it was most lovely and enjoyable . Also [they]483-the children made wreaths of flowers and hung them upon the tree and about the spring to please [the fairies that lived there]486-the fairies that lived there ; for [they]483-the children liked that , being [idle innocent little creatures]487-idle innocent little creatures , as [all fairies]488-all fairies are , and fond of anything delicate and pretty like wild flowers put together in that way . And in return for this attention [the fairies]489-the fairies did any friendly thing [they]489-the fairies could for [the children]483-the children , such as keeping the spring always full and clear and cold , and driving away serpents and insects that sting ; and so there was never any unkindness between [the fairies]489-the fairies and [the children]483-the children during more than five hundred years — tradition said a thousand — but only the warmest affection and the most perfect trust and confidence ; and whenever [a child]327-a child died [the fairies]489-the fairies mourned just as [[that child]495-that child ’s playmates]496-that child ’s playmates did , and the sign of it was there to see ; for before the dawn on the day of the funeral [they]489-the fairies hung a little immortelle over the place where [that child]495-that child was used to sit under the tree . [I]0-i know this to be true by [my]0-i own eyes ; it is not hearsay . And the reason it was known that [the fairies]489-the fairies did it was this — that it was made all of black flowers of a sort not known in [France]4-france anywhere . Now from time immemorial [all children reared in]499-all children reared in [Domremy]1-domremy were called [the Children of the Tree]500-the children of the tree ; and [they]499-all children reared in loved that name , for it carried with it a mystic privilege not granted to [any others of [the children of [this world]345-this world]502-the children of this world]501-any others of the children of this world . Which was this : whenever one of these came to die , then beyond the vague and formless images drifting through [his]504-his darkening mind rose soft and rich and fair a vision of the Tree — if all was well with [his]504-his soul . That was what [some]505-some said . [Others]506-others said the vision came in two ways : once as a warning , one or two years in advance of death , when the soul was [the captive of sin]507-the captive of sin , and then the Tree appeared in its desolate winter aspect — then [that soul]508-that soul was smitten with an awful fear . If repentance came , and purity of life , the vision came again , this time summer - clad and beautiful ; but if it were otherwise with that soul the vision was withheld , and it passed from life knowing its doom . Still [others]506-others said that the vision came but once , and then only to the sinless dying forlorn in [distant lands]510-distant lands and pitifully longing for some last dear reminder of [[their]505-some home]511-their home . And what reminder of it could go to [their]505-some hearts like the picture of the Tree that was the darling of [their]505-some love and the comrade of [their]505-some joys and comforter of [their]505-some small griefs all through the divine days of [their]505-some vanished youth ? Now the several traditions were as [I]0-i have said , some believing one and some another . One of them [I]0-i knew to be the truth , and that was the last one . [I]0-i do not say anything against the others ; [I]0-i think they were true , but [I]0-i only know that [the last one]512-the last one was ; and it is [my]0-i thought that if [one]461-one keep to the things [he]461-one knows , and not trouble about the things which [he]461-one can not be sure about , [he]461-one will have the steadier mind for it — and there is profit in that . [I]0-i know that when [the Children of the Tree]500-the children of the tree die in [a far land]515-a far land , then — if [they]500-the children of the tree be at peace with [God]140-god — [they]500-the children of the tree turn [their]500-the children of the tree longing eyes toward [home]377-home , and there , far - shining , as through a rift in a cloud that curtains heaven , [they]500-the children of the tree see the soft picture of the Fairy Tree , clothed in a dream of golden light ; and [they]500-the children of the tree see the bloomy mead sloping away to [the river]454-the river , and to [their]500-the children of the tree perishing nostrils is blown faint and sweet the fragrance of the flowers of [home]377-home . And then the vision fades and passes — but [they]500-the children of the tree know , [they]500-the children of the tree know ! and by [their]500-the children of the tree transfigured faces [you]519-you know also , [you]519-you who stand looking on ; yes , [you]519-you know the message that has come , and that it has come from [heaven]520-heaven . [Joan]110-joan and [I]0-i believed alike about this matter . But [Pierre Morel]132-pierre and [Jacques d’Arc]130-jacques , and [many others]521-many others believed that the vision appeared twice — to [a sinner]522-a sinner . In fact , [they]500-the children of the tree and [many others]521-many others said [they]500-the children of the tree knew it . Probably because [[their]500-the children of the tree fathers]524-their fathers had known it and had told [them]500-the children of the tree ; for one gets most things at second hand in [this world]345-this world . Now one thing that does make it quite likely that there were [really two apparitions of the Tree]526-really two apparitions of the tree is this fact : From the most ancient times if one saw [a villager of [ours]528-ours]527-a villager of ours with [his]527-a villager of ours face ash - white and rigid with a ghastly fright , it was common for [every one]529-every one to whisper to [[his]529-every one neighbor]530-his neighbor , “ Ah , [he]527-a villager of ours is in sin , and has got [his]527-a villager of ours warning . ”[529-every one] And [the neighbor]531-the neighbor would shudder at the thought and whisper back , “ Yes , [poor soul]2323-poor soul , [he]527-a villager of ours has seen the Tree . ”[531-the neighbor] Such evidences as these have [their]532-their weight ; they are not to be put aside with a wave of the hand . A thing that is backed by the cumulative evidence of centuries naturally gets nearer and nearer to being proof all the time ; and if this continue and continue , it will some day become authority — and authority is a bedded rock , and will abide . In [my]0-i long life [I]0-i have seen several cases where the tree appeared announcing a death which was still far away ; but in none of these was [the person in a state of sin]533-the person in a state of sin . No ; the apparition was in these cases only a special grace ; in place of deferring the tidings of [that soul]508-that soul ’s redemption till the day of death , [the apparition]535-the apparition brought [them]508-that soul long before , and with [them]508-that soul peace — peace that might no more be disturbed — the eternal peace of [God]140-god . [I]0-i [myself]0-i , old and broken , wait with serenity ; for [I]0-i have seen the vision of the Tree . [I]0-i have seen it , and am content . Always , from the remotest times , when [the children]483-the children joined hands and danced around [the Fairy Tree]30-the fairy tree [they]483-the children sang a song which was the [Tree]141-tree ’s song , the song of L’Arbre Fee de [Bourlemont]31-bourlemont . [They]483-the children sang it to a quaint sweet air — a solacing sweet air which has gone murmuring through [my]0-i dreaming spirit all [my]0-i life when [I]0-i was weary and troubled , resting [me]0-i and carrying [me]0-i through night and distance [home]377-home again . [No stranger]538-no stranger can know or feel what that song has been , through the drifting centuries , to [exiled Children of the Tree]539-exiled children of the tree , homeless and heavy of heart in countries foreign to [their]539-exiled children of the tree speech and ways . [You]540-you will think it a simple thing , that song , and poor , perchance ; but if [you]540-you will remember what it was to [us]541-our , and what it brought before [our]541-our eyes when it floated through [our]541-our memories , then [you]540-you will respect it . And [you]540-you will understand how the water wells up in [our]541-our eyes and makes all things dim , and [our]541-our voices break and [we]541-our can not sing the last lines : “ And when , in Exile wand’ring , [we]541-our Shall fainting yearn for glimpse of [thee]2324-thee , Oh , rise upon [our]541-our sight ! ”[540-you] And [you]540-you will remember that [Joan of Arc]110-joan sang this song with [us]541-our around the Tree when [she]110-joan was [a little child]542-a little child , and always loved it . And that hallows it , yes , [you]540-you will grant that : L’ARBRE FEE DE [BOURLEMONT]31-bourlemont SONG OF [THE CHILDREN]483-the children Now what has kept [your]540-you leaves so green , Arbre Fee de [Bourlemont]31-bourlemont ? [The children]483-the children ’s tears ! [They]483-the children brought each grief , And [you]540-you did comfort [them]483-the children and cheer [Their]483-the children bruised hearts , and steal a tear That , healed , rose a leaf . And what has built [you]540-you up so strong , Arbre Fee de [Bourlemont]31-bourlemont ? [The children]483-the children ’s love ! [They]483-the children ’ve loved [you]540-you long Ten hundred years , in sooth , [They]483-the children ’ve nourished [you]540-you with praise and song , And warmed [your]540-you heart and kept it young — A thousand years of youth ! Bide always green in [our]546-we young hearts , [Arbre Fee de Bourlemont]32-arbre fee de bourlemont ! And [we]546-we shall always youthful be , Not heeding Time [his]547-his flight ; And when , in exile wand’ring , [we]546-we Shall fainting yearn for glimpse of [thee]548-thee , Oh , rise upon [our]546-we sight ! [The fairies]489-the fairies were still there when [we]546-we were [children]550-children , but [we]546-we never saw [them]489-the fairies ; because , a hundred years before that , [the priest of [Domremy]1-domremy]551-the priest of domremy had held a religious function under the tree and denounced [them]489-the fairies as being blood - kin to [the Fiend]552-the fiend and barred [them]489-the fairies from redemption ; and then [he]551-the priest of domremy warned [them]489-the fairies never to show [themselves]489-the fairies again , nor hang any more immortelles , on pain of perpetual banishment from [that parish]553-that parish . [All the children]554-all the children pleaded for [the fairies]489-the fairies , and said [they]489-the fairies were [[their]554-all the children good friends]556-their good friends and dear to [them]554-all the children and never did [them]554-all the children any harm , but [the priest]399-the priest would not listen , and said it was sin and shame to have [such friends]558-such friends . [The children]483-the children mourned and could not be comforted ; and [they]483-the children made an agreement among [themselves]483-the children that [they]483-the children would always continue to hang flower - wreaths on the tree as a perpetual sign to [the fairies]489-the fairies that [they]489-the fairies were still loved and remembered , though lost to sight . But late one night a great misfortune befell . [[Edmond Aubrey]136-edmond aubrey ’s mother]561-edmond aubrey ’s mother passed by the Tree , and [the fairies]489-the fairies were stealing a dance , not thinking [anybody]563-anybody was by ; and [they]489-the fairies were so busy , and so intoxicated with the wild happiness of it , and with the bumpers of dew sharpened up with honey which [they]489-the fairies had been drinking , that [they]489-the fairies noticed nothing ; so [Dame Aubrey]143-dame aubrey stood there astonished and admiring , and saw the little fantastic atoms holding hands , as many as three hundred of [them]489-the fairies , tearing around in a great ring half as big as [an ordinary bedroom]564-an ordinary bedroom , and leaning away back and spreading [their]489-the fairies mouths with laughter and song , which [she]143-dame aubrey could hear quite distinctly , and kicking [their]489-the fairies legs up as much as three inches from the ground in perfect abandon and hilarity — oh , the very maddest and witchingest dance [the woman]565-the woman ever saw . But in about a minute or two minutes the poor little ruined creatures discovered [her]143-dame aubrey . [They]489-the fairies burst out in one heartbreaking squeak of grief and terror and fled every which way , with [their]489-the fairies wee hazel - nut fists in [their]489-the fairies eyes and crying ; and so disappeared . [The heartless woman]566-the heartless woman — no , [the foolish woman]567-the foolish woman ; [she]566-the heartless woman was not heartless , but only thoughtless — went straight [home]377-home and told [the neighbors]569-the neighbors all about it , whilst [we]570-we , [the small friends of [the fairies]489-the fairies]571-the small friends of the fairies , were asleep and not witting the calamity that was come upon [us]570-we , and all unconscious that [we]570-we ought to be up and trying to stop these fatal tongues . In the morning [everybody]464-everybody knew , and the disaster was complete , for where [everybody]464-everybody knows a thing [the priest]399-the priest knows it , of course . [We]570-we all flocked to [Pere Fronte]129-pere fronte , crying and begging — and [he]129-pere fronte had to cry , too , seeing [our]570-we sorrow , for [he]129-pere fronte had a most kind and gentle nature ; and [he]129-pere fronte did not want to banish [the fairies]489-the fairies , and said so ; but said [he]129-pere fronte had no choice , for it had been decreed that if [they]489-the fairies ever revealed [themselves]489-the fairies to [man]577-man again , [they]489-the fairies must go . This all happened at the worst time possible , for [Joan of Arc]110-joan was ill of a fever and out of [her]110-joan head , and what could [we]570-we do who had not [her]110-joan gifts of reasoning and persuasion ? [We]570-we flew in a swarm to [her]110-joan bed and cried out , “ [Joan]110-joan , wake ! Wake , there is no moment to lose ! Come and plead for [the fairies]489-the fairies — come and save [them]489-the fairies ; only [you]110-joan can do it ! ”[570-we] But [her]110-joan mind was wandering , [she]110-joan did not know what [we]570-we said nor what [we]570-we meant ; so [we]570-we went away knowing all was lost . Yes , all was lost , forever lost ; [the faithful friends of [the children]483-the children]578-the faithful friends of the children for five hundred years must go , and never come back any more . It was a bitter day for [us]570-we , that day that [Pere Fronte]129-pere fronte held the function under the tree and banished [the fairies]489-the fairies . [We]570-we could not wear mourning that any could have noticed , it would not have been allowed ; so [we]570-we had to be content with some poor small rag of black tied upon [our]570-we garments where it made no show ; but in [our]570-we hearts [we]570-we wore mourning , big and noble and occupying all the room , for [our]570-we hearts were [ours]570-we ; [they]581-they could not get at [them]581-they to prevent that . The great tree — l’Arbre Fee de Bourlemont was its beautiful name — was never afterward quite as much to [us]570-we as it had been before , but it was always dear ; is dear to [me]0-i yet when [I]0-i go [there]460-there now , once a year in [my]0-i old age , to sit under it and bring back [the lost playmates of [my]0-i youth]583-the lost playmates of my youth and group [them]583-the lost playmates of my youth about [me]0-i and look upon [their]583-the lost playmates of my youth faces through [my]0-i tears and break [my]0-i heart , oh , [[my]0-i God]584-my god ! No , [the place]585-the place was not quite the same afterward . In one or two ways it could not be ; for , [the fairies]489-the fairies ’ protection being gone , the spring lost much of its freshness and coldness , and more than two - thirds of [its]587-its volume , and the banished serpents and stinging insects returned , and multiplied , and became a torment and have remained so to this day . When [that wise little child]588-that wise little child , [Joan]110-joan , got well , [we]570-we realized how much [her]588-that wise little child illness had cost [us]570-we ; for [we]570-we found that [we]570-we had been right in believing [she]588-that wise little child could save [the fairies]489-the fairies . [She]588-that wise little child burst into a great storm of anger , for [so little a creature]590-so little a creature , and went straight to [Pere Fronte]129-pere fronte , and stood up before [him]129-pere fronte where [he]129-pere fronte sat , and made reverence and said : “ [The fairies]489-the fairies were to go if [they]489-the fairies showed [themselves]489-the fairies to [people]2327-people again , is it not so ? ”[588-that wise little child] “ Yes , that was it , [dear]2328-dear . ”[591-the good priest] “ If [a man]2329-a man comes prying into [[a person]467-a person ’s room]2331-a person ’s room at midnight when [that person]2332-that person is half - naked , will [you]591-the good priest be so unjust as to say that [that person]2332-that person is showing [himself]2332-that person to [that man]2334-that man ? ”[591-the good priest] “ Well — no . ”[591-the good priest] [The good priest]591-the good priest looked a little troubled and uneasy when [he]591-the good priest said it . “ Is a sin a sin , anyway , even if [one]461-one did not intend to commit it ? ”[591-the good priest] [Pere Fronte]129-pere fronte threw up [his]129-pere fronte hands and cried out : “ Oh , [[my]129-pere fronte poor little child]2336-my poor little child , [I]129-pere fronte see all [my]129-pere fronte fault , ”[129-pere fronte] and [he]129-pere fronte drew [her]592-her to [his]129-pere fronte side and put an arm around [her]592-her and tried to make [his]129-pere fronte peace with [her]592-her , but [her]592-her temper was up so high that [she]592-her could not get it down right away , but buried [her]592-her head against [his]129-pere fronte breast and broke out crying and said : “ Then [the fairies]489-the fairies committed no sin , for there was no intention to commit one , [they]489-the fairies not knowing that [any one]2338-any one was by ; and because [they]489-the fairies were [little creatures]2339-little creatures and could not speak for [themselves]489-the fairies and say the law was against the intention , not against the innocent act , because [they]489-the fairies had [no friend]2340-no friend to think that simple thing for [them]489-the fairies and say it , [they]489-the fairies have been sent away from [[their]489-the fairies home]511-their home forever , and it was wrong , wrong to do it ! ”[592-her] [The good father]593-the good father hugged [her]592-her yet closer to [his]593-the good father side and said : “ Oh , out of the mouths of [babes and sucklings]2342-babes and sucklings [the heedless and unthinking]2343-the heedless and unthinking are condemned ; would [God]140-god [I]593-the good father could bring [the little creatures]2344-the little creatures back , for [your]592-her sake . And [mine]593-the good father , yes , and [mine]593-the good father ; for [I]593-the good father have been unjust . There , there , do n’t cry — [nobody]434-nobody could be sorrier than [[your]592-her poor old friend]2346-your poor old friend — don’t cry , [dear]2328-dear . ”[593-the good father] “ But [I]129-pere fronte ca n’t stop right away , [I]129-pere fronte ’ve got to . And it is no little matter , this thing that [you]592-her have done . Is being sorry penance enough for such an act ? ”[129-pere fronte] [Pere Fronte]129-pere fronte turned away [his]129-pere fronte face , for it would have hurt [her]592-her to see [him]129-pere fronte laugh , and said : “ Oh , [thou]592-her remorseless but [most just accuser]2348-most just accuser , no , it is not . [I]592-her will put on sackcloth and ashes ; there — are [you]592-her satisfied ? ”[592-her] [Joan]110-joan ’s sobs began to diminish , and [she]592-her presently looked up at [the old man]594-the old man through [her]592-her tears , and said , in [her]592-her simple way : “ Yes , that will do — if it will clear [you]594-the old man . ”[592-her] [Pere Fronte]129-pere fronte would have been moved to laugh again , perhaps , if [he]594-the old man had not remembered in time that [he]594-the old man had made a contract , and not a very agreeable one . It must be fulfilled . So [he]594-the old man got up and went to the fireplace , [Joan]110-joan watching [him]594-the old man with deep interest , and took a shovelful of cold ashes , and was going to empty them on [his]594-the old man old gray head when a better idea came to [him]594-the old man , and [he]594-the old man said : “ Would [you]110-joan mind helping [me]594-the old man , [dear]2328-dear ? ”[594-the old man] “ How , [father]2350-father ? ”[594-the old man] [He]594-the old man got down on [his]594-the old man knees and bent [his]594-the old man head low , and said : “ Take the ashes and put them on [my]594-the old man head for [me]594-the old man . ”[594-the old man] The matter ended there , of course . The victory was with [the priest]399-the priest . [One]461-one can imagine how the idea of such a profanation would strike [Joan]110-joan or [any other child in [the village]401-the village]597-any other child in the village . [She]110-joan ran and dropped upon [her]110-joan knees by [his]594-the old man side and said : “ Oh , it is dreadful . [I]110-joan did n’t know that that was what one meant by sackcloth and ashes — do please get up , [father]2350-father . ”[110-joan] “ But [I]110-joan ca n’t until [I]110-joan am forgiven . Do [you]2350-father forgive [me]110-joan ? ”[110-joan] “ [I]110-joan ? Oh , [you]2350-father have done nothing to [me]110-joan , [father]2350-father ; it is [yourself]2350-father that must forgive [yourself]2350-father for wronging those poor things . Please get up , [father]2350-father , wo n’t [you]2350-father ? ”[110-joan] “ But [I]110-joan am worse off now than [I]110-joan was before . [I]110-joan thought [I]110-joan was earning [your]2350-father forgiveness , but if it is [my]110-joan own , [I]110-joan ca n’t be lenient ; it would not become [me]110-joan . Now what can [I]110-joan do ? Find [me]110-joan some way out of this with [your]2350-father wise little head . ”[110-joan] [The Pere]599-the pere would not stir , for all [Joan]110-joan ’s pleadings . [She]110-joan was about to cry again ; then [she]110-joan had an idea , and seized the shovel and deluged [her]110-joan own head with the ashes , stammering out through [her]110-joan chokings and suffocations : “ There — now it is done . Oh , please get up , [father]2350-father . ”[110-joan] [The old man]594-the old man , both touched and amused , gathered [her]110-joan to [his]594-the old man breast and said : “ Oh , [[you]110-joan incomparable child]2355-you incomparable child ! It ’s a humble martyrdom , and not of a sort presentable in a picture , but the right and true spirit is in it ; that [I]594-the old man testify . ”[594-the old man] Then [he]594-the old man brushed the ashes out of [her]110-joan hair , and helped [her]110-joan scour [her]110-joan face and neck and properly tidy [herself]110-joan up . [He]594-the old man was in fine spirits now , and ready for further argument , so [he]594-the old man took [his]594-the old man seat and drew [Joan]110-joan to [his]594-the old man side again , and said : “ [Joan]110-joan , [you]110-joan were used to make wreaths there at [the Fairy Tree]2356-the fairy tree with [the other children]2357-the other children ; is it not so ? ”[594-the old man] That was the way [he]594-the old man always started out when [he]594-the old man was going to corner [me]0-i up and catch [me]0-i in something — just that gentle , indifferent way that fools [a person]467-a person so , and leads [him]467-a person into the trap , [he]594-the old man never noticing which way [he]594-the old man is traveling until [he]594-the old man is in and the door shut on [him]594-the old man . [He]594-the old man enjoyed that . [I]0-i knew [he]594-the old man was going to drop corn along in front of [Joan]110-joan now . [Joan]110-joan answered : “ Yes , [father]2350-father . ”[110-joan] “ Did [you]594-the old man hang them on the tree ? ”[110-joan] “ No , [father]2350-father . ”[110-joan] “ Did n’t hang them there ? ”[110-joan] “ No . ”[110-joan] “ Why did n’t [you]594-the old man ? ”[110-joan] “ [I]110-joan — well , [I]110-joan did n’t wish to . ”[110-joan] “ Did n’t wish to ? ”[110-joan] “ No , [father]2350-father . ”[110-joan] “ What did [you]594-the old man do with [them]2361-them ? ”[110-joan] “ [I]110-joan hung them in [the church]409-the church . ”[110-joan] “ Why did n’t [you]594-the old man want to hang [them]2361-them in the tree ? ”[110-joan] “ Because it was said that [the fairies]489-the fairies were of kin to [the Fiend]552-the fiend , and that it was sinful to show [them]489-the fairies honor . ”[110-joan] “ Did [you]594-the old man believe it was wrong to honor [them]489-the fairies so ? ”[110-joan] “ Yes . [I]110-joan thought it must be wrong . ”[110-joan] “ Then if it was wrong to honor [them]489-the fairies in that way , and if [they]489-the fairies were of kin to [the Fiend]552-the fiend , [they]489-the fairies could be dangerous company for [you]0-i and [the other children]2357-the other children , could n’t [they]489-the fairies ? ”[110-joan] “ [I]110-joan suppose so — yes , [I]110-joan think so . ”[110-joan] [He]602-he studied a minute , and [I]0-i judged [he]602-he was going to spring [his]602-he trap , and [he]602-he did . [He]602-he said : “ Then the matter stands like this . [They]489-the fairies were [banned creatures , of fearful origin]2367-banned creatures , of fearful origin ; [they]489-the fairies could be dangerous company for [the children]483-the children . Now give [me]602-he a rational reason , [dear]2328-dear , if [you]2328-dear can think of any , why [you]2328-dear call it a wrong to drive [them]489-the fairies into banishment , and why [you]2328-dear would have saved [them]489-the fairies from it . In a word , what loss have [you]2328-dear suffered by it ? ”[602-he] How stupid of [him]602-he to go and throw [his]602-he case away like that ! [I]0-i could have boxed [his]602-he ears for vexation if [he]602-he had been [a boy]603-a boy . [He]602-he was going along all right until [he]602-he ruined everything by winding up in that foolish and fatal way . What had [she]604-her lost by it ! Was [he]602-he never going to find out what kind of [a child]327-a child [Joan of Arc]110-joan was ? Was [he]602-he never going to learn that things which merely concerned [her]604-her own gain or loss [she]604-her cared nothing about ? Could [he]602-he never get the simple fact into [his]602-he head that the sure way and the only way to rouse [her]604-her up and set [her]604-her on fire was to show [her]604-her where [some other person]606-some other person was going to suffer wrong or hurt or loss ? Why , [he]602-he had gone and set a trap for [himself]602-he — that was all [he]602-he had accomplished . The minute those words were out of [his]602-he mouth [her]604-her temper was up , the indignant tears rose in [her]604-her eyes , and [she]604-her burst out on [him]602-he with an energy and passion which astonished [him]602-he , but did n’t astonish [me]0-i , for [I]0-i knew [he]602-he had fired a mine when [he]602-he touched off [his]602-he ill - chosen climax . “ Oh , [father]2350-father , how can [you]2350-father talk like that ? Who owns [France]4-france ? ”[607-she] “ [God]140-god and [the King]270-the king . ”[604-her] “ Not [Satan]144-satan ? ”[604-her] “ [Satan]144-satan , [[my]607-she child]2372-my child ? This is the footstool of the Most High — [Satan]144-satan owns no handful of [[its]4-france soil]2373-its soil . ”[607-she] “ Then who gave [those poor creatures]2374-those poor creatures [[their]2374-those poor creatures home]511-their home ? [God]140-god . Who protected [them]2374-those poor creatures in it all those centuries ? [God]140-god . Who allowed [them]2374-those poor creatures to dance and play there all those centuries and found no fault with it ? [God]140-god . Who disapproved of [God]140-god ’s approval and put a threat upon [them]2374-those poor creatures ? [A man]2329-a man . Who caught [them]2374-those poor creatures again in harmless sports that [God]140-god allowed and [a man]2329-a man forbade , and carried out that threat , and drove [the poor things]2378-the poor things away from [the home]2379-the home [the good God]2380-the good god gave [them]2374-those poor creatures in [His]140-god mercy and [His]140-god pity , and sent down [His]140-god rain and dew and sunshine upon it five hundred years in token of [His]140-god peace ? It was [[their]2374-those poor creatures home]511-their home — [theirs]2374-those poor creatures , by the grace of [God]140-god and [His]140-god good heart , and [no man]359-no man had a right to rob [them]2374-those poor creatures of it . And [they]2374-those poor creatures were [the gentlest , truest friends that [children]550-children ever had]2383-the gentlest , truest friends that children ever had , and did [them]2374-those poor creatures sweet and loving service all these five long centuries , and never any hurt or harm ; and [the children]483-the children loved [them]2374-those poor creatures , and now [they]483-the children mourn for [them]2374-those poor creatures , and there is no healing for [their]2374-those poor creatures grief . And what had [the children]483-the children done that [they]483-the children should suffer this cruel stroke ? [The poor fairies]2387-the poor fairies could have been dangerous company for [the children]483-the children ? Yes , but never had been ; and could is no argument . [Kinsmen of the Fiend]2389-kinsmen of the fiend ? What of it ? [Kinsmen of the Fiend]2389-kinsmen of the fiend have rights , and these had ; and [children]550-children have rights , and these had ; and if [I]607-she had been [there]460-there [I]607-she would have spoken — [I]607-she would have begged for [the children]483-the children and [the fiends]2394-the fiends , and stayed [your]2395-your hand and saved [them]483-the children all . But now — oh , now , all is lost ; everything is lost , and there is no help more ! ”[607-she] Then [she]607-she finished with a blast at that idea that [fairy kinsmen of the Fiend]608-fairy kinsmen of the fiend ought to be shunned and denied human sympathy and friendship because salvation was barred against [them]608-fairy kinsmen of the fiend . [She]607-she said that for that very reason [people]2327-people ought to pity [them]608-fairy kinsmen of the fiend , and do every humane and loving thing [they]2327-people could to make [them]608-fairy kinsmen of the fiend forget the hard fate that had been put upon [them]608-fairy kinsmen of the fiend by accident of birth and no fault of [their]608-fairy kinsmen of the fiend own . “ [Poor little creatures]2396-poor little creatures ! ”[607-she] [she]607-she said . “ What can [a person]467-a person ’s heart be made of that can pity [a Christian ’s child]2398-a christian ’s child and yet ca n’t pity [a devil ’s child , that a thousand times more]2399-a devil ’s child , that a thousand times more needs it ! ”[607-she] [She]607-she had torn loose from [Pere Fronte]129-pere fronte , and was crying , with [her]607-she knuckles in [her]607-she eyes , and stamping [her]607-she small feet in a fury ; and now [she]607-she burst out of [the place]585-the place and was gone before [we]611-we could gather [our]611-we senses together out of this storm of words and this whirlwind of passion . [The Pere]129-pere fronte had got upon [his]129-pere fronte feet , toward the last , and now [he]129-pere fronte stood there passing [his]129-pere fronte hand back and forth across [his]129-pere fronte forehead like [a person who is dazed and troubled]612-a person who is dazed and troubled ; then [he]129-pere fronte turned and wandered toward the door of [[his]129-pere fronte little workroom]613-his little workroom , and as [he]129-pere fronte passed through [it]614-it [I]0-i heard [him]129-pere fronte murmur sorrowfully : “ Ah , [me]129-pere fronte , [poor children]2400-poor children , [poor fiends]2401-poor fiends , [they]2401-poor fiends have rights , and [she]2402-she said true — [I]129-pere fronte never thought of that . [God]140-god forgive [me]129-pere fronte , [I]129-pere fronte am to blame . ”[129-pere fronte] When [I]0-i heard that , [I]0-i knew [I]0-i was right in the thought that [he]129-pere fronte had set a trap for [himself]129-pere fronte . It was so , and [he]129-pere fronte had walked into it , [you]615-you see . [I]0-i seemed to feel encouraged , and wondered if mayhap [I]0-i might get [him]129-pere fronte into one ; but upon reflection [my]0-i heart went down , for this was not [my]0-i gift . Chapter 3 All Aflame with Love of [France]145-france SPEAKING of this matter reminds [me]0-i of many incidents , many things that [I]0-i could tell , but [I]0-i think [I]0-i will not try to do it now . It will be more to [my]0-i present humor to call back a little glimpse of the simple and colorless good times [we]616-we used to have in [[our]616-we village homes]617-our village homes in those peaceful days — especially in the winter . In the summer [[we]616-we [children]550-children]446-we children were out on [the breezy uplands]620-the breezy uplands with the flocks from dawn till night , and then there was noisy frolicking and all that ; but winter was the cozy time , winter was the snug time . Often [we]616-we gathered in [[old Jacques d’Arc]621-old jacques d’arc ’s big dirt - floored apartment]622-old jacques d’arc ’s big dirt - floored apartment , with a great fire going , and played games , and sang songs , and told fortunes , and listened to [the old villagers]623-the old villagers tell tales and histories and lies and one thing and another till twelve o’clock at night . One winter ’s night [we]616-we were gathered [there]460-there — it was the winter that for years afterward [they]623-the old villagers called the hard winter — and that particular night was a sharp one . It blew a gale outside , and the screaming of the wind was a stirring sound , and [I]0-i think [I]0-i may say it was beautiful , for [I]0-i think it is great and fine and beautiful to hear the wind rage and storm and blow its clarions like that , when [you]625-you are inside and comfortable . And [we]616-we were . [We]616-we had a roaring fire , and the pleasant spit - spit of the snow and sleet falling in it down the chimney , and the yarning and laughing and singing went on at a noble rate till about ten o’clock , and then [we]616-we had a supper of hot porridge and beans , and meal cakes with butter , and appetites to match . [Little Joan]110-joan sat on a box apart , and had [her]110-joan bowl and bread on another one , and [her]110-joan pets around [her]110-joan helping . [She]110-joan had more than was usual of [them]623-the old villagers or economical , because [all the outcast cats]626-all the outcast cats came and took up with [her]110-joan , and [homeless or unlovable animals of other kinds]627-homeless or unlovable animals of other kinds heard about it and came , and these spread the matter to the other creatures , and [they]623-the old villagers came also ; and as the birds and the other timid wild things of [the woods]628-the woods were not afraid of [her]110-joan , but always had an idea [she]110-joan was [a friend]629-a friend when [they]623-the old villagers came across [her]110-joan , and generally struck up an acquaintance with [her]110-joan to get invited to [the house]630-the house , [she]110-joan always had samples of those breeds in stock . [She]110-joan was hospitable to [them]623-the old villagers all , for an animal was an animal to [her]110-joan , and dear by mere reason of being an animal , no matter about [its]631-its sort or social station ; and as [she]110-joan would allow of no cages , no collars , no fetters , but left [the creatures]632-the creatures free to come and go as [they]632-the creatures liked , that contented [them]632-the creatures , and [they]632-the creatures came ; but [they]632-the creatures did n’t go , to any extent , and so [they]632-the creatures were a marvelous nuisance , and made [Jacques]130-jacques d’Arc swear a good deal ; but [[his]130-jacques wife]412-his wife said [God]140-god gave [the child]634-the child the instinct , and knew what [He]130-jacques was doing when [He]130-jacques did it , therefore it must have its course ; it would be no sound prudence to meddle with [His]130-jacques affairs when no invitation had been extended . So the pets were left in peace , and here [they]632-the creatures were , as [I]0-i have said , rabbits , birds , squirrels , cats , and other reptiles , all around [the child]634-the child , and full of interest in [her]634-the child supper , and helping what [they]632-the creatures could . There was a very small squirrel on [her]110-joan shoulder , sitting up , as those creatures do , and turning a rocky fragment of prehistoric chestnut - cake over and over in its knotty hands , and hunting for the less indurated places , and giving its elevated bushy tail a flirt and its pointed ears a toss when it found one — signifying thankfulness and surprise — and then it filed that place off with those two slender front teeth which a squirrel carries for that purpose and not for ornament , for ornamental [they]632-the creatures never could be , as any will admit that have noticed [them]632-the creatures . Everything was going fine and breezy and hilarious , but then there came an interruption , for [somebody]636-somebody hammered on the door . It was one of [those ragged road - stragglers]637-those ragged road - stragglers — the eternal wars kept [the country]315-the country full of [them]637-those ragged road - stragglers . [He]636-somebody came in , all over snow , and stamped [his]636-somebody feet , and shook , and brushed [himself]636-somebody , and shut the door , and took off [his]636-somebody limp ruin of a hat , and slapped it once or twice against [his]636-somebody leg to knock off its fleece of snow , and then glanced around on [the company]639-the company with a pleased look upon [his]636-somebody thin face , and a most yearning and famished one in [his]636-somebody eye when it fell upon the victuals , and then [he]636-somebody gave [us]640-us a humble and conciliatory salutation , and said it was a blessed thing to have a fire like that on such a night , and a roof overhead like this , and that rich food to eat , and loving [friends to talk with]641-friends to talk with — ah , yes , this was true , and [God]140-god help [the homeless]642-the homeless , and such as must trudge [the roads]643-the roads in this weather . [Nobody]434-nobody said anything . [The embarrassed poor creature]645-the embarrassed poor creature stood there and appealed to one face after [the other]646-the other with [his]645-the embarrassed poor creature eyes , and found no welcome in any , the smile on [his]645-the embarrassed poor creature own face flickering and fading and perishing , meanwhile ; then [he]645-the embarrassed poor creature dropped [his]645-the embarrassed poor creature gaze , the muscles of [his]645-the embarrassed poor creature face began to twitch , and [he]645-the embarrassed poor creature put up [his]645-the embarrassed poor creature hand to cover this womanish sign of weakness . “ Sit down ! ”[645-the embarrassed poor creature] This thunder - blast was from old Jacques d’Arc , and [Joan]110-joan was the object of it . [The stranger]647-the stranger was startled , and took [his]647-the stranger hand away , and there was [Joan]110-joan standing before [him]647-the stranger offering [him]647-the stranger [her]110-joan bowl of porridge . [The man]648-the man said : “ God Almighty bless [you]110-joan , [[my]648-the man darling]2403-my darling ! ”[648-the man] and then the tears came , and ran down [his]647-the stranger cheeks , but [he]647-the stranger was afraid to take the bowl . “ Do [you]650-her father hear [me]647-the stranger ? Sit down , [I]647-the stranger say ! ”[647-the stranger] There could not be [a child]327-a child more easy to persuade than [Joan]110-joan , but this was not the way . [[Her]110-joan father]650-her father had not the art ; neither could [he]650-her father learn it . [Joan]110-joan said : “ [Father]2350-father , [he]647-the stranger is hungry ; [I]110-joan can see it . ”[110-joan] “ Let [him]647-the stranger work for food , then . [We]2405-we are being eaten out of [house]2406-house and [home]377-home by [[his]647-the stranger like]2408-his like , and [I]651-i have said [I]651-i would endure it no more , and will keep [my]651-i word . [He]647-the stranger has the face of [a rascal]2409-a rascal anyhow , and [a villain]2410-a villain . Sit down , [I]651-i tell [you]2350-father ! ”[651-i] “ [I]651-i know not if [he]647-the stranger is [a rascal]2409-a rascal or no , but [he]647-the stranger is hungry , [father]2350-father , and shall have [my]651-i porridge — [I]651-i do not need it . ”[651-i] “ If [you]2350-father do n’t obey [me]651-i I’ll — [Rascals]2413-rascals are not entitled to help from [honest people]2414-honest people , and no bite nor sup shall [they]2413-rascals have in [this house]2415-this house . [Joan]110-joan ! ”[651-i] [She]651-i set [her]651-i bowl down on the box and came over and stood before [[her]651-i scowling father]652-her scowling father , and said : “ [Father]2350-father , if [you]2350-father will not let [me]651-i , then it must be as [you]2350-father say ; but [I]651-i would that [you]2350-father would think — then [you]2350-father would see that it is not right to punish one part of [him]652-her scowling father for what the other part has done ; for it is [that poor stranger]2417-that poor stranger ’s head that does the evil things , but it is not [his]652-her scowling father head that is hungry , it is [his]652-her scowling father stomach , and it has done no harm to [anybody]563-anybody , but is without blame , and innocent , not having any way to do a wrong , even if it was minded to it . Please let — ”[651-i] “ What an idea ! It is the most idiotic speech [I]651-i ever heard . ”[651-i] But [Aubrey]143-dame aubrey , [the maire]653-the maire , broke in , [he]653-the maire being fond of an argument , and having a pretty gift in that regard , as all acknowledged . Rising in [his]652-her scowling father place and leaning [his]652-her scowling father knuckles upon the table and looking about [him]652-her scowling father with easy dignity , after the manner of [such as be orators]654-such as be orators , [he]652-her scowling father began , smooth and persuasive : “ [I]652-her scowling father will differ with [you]655-you there , [gossip]2419-gossip , and will undertake to show the company”—here[652-her scowling father] [he]652-her scowling father looked around upon [us]655-you and nodded [his]652-her scowling father head in a confident way—“that there is a grain of sense in what [the child]634-the child has said ; for look [you]655-you , it is of a certainty most true and demonstrable that it is [a man]2329-a man ’s head that is [master]2422-master and [supreme ruler over [his]2329-a man whole body]2423-supreme ruler over his whole body . Is that granted ? Will any deny it ? ”[652-her scowling father] [He]652-her scowling father glanced around again ; [everybody]464-everybody indicated assent . “ Very well , then ; that being the case , [no part of the body]2424-no part of the body is responsible for the result when [it]2425-it carries out an order delivered to [it]2425-it by [the head]2426-the head ; ergo , the head is alone responsible for crimes done by [a man]2329-a man ’s hands or feet or stomach — do [you]655-you get the idea ? am [I]464-everybody right thus far ? ”[464-everybody] [Everybody]464-everybody said yes , and said it with enthusiasm , and [some]505-some said , one to another , that [the maire]653-the maire was in great form to - night and at [his]653-the maire very best — which pleased [the maire]653-the maire exceedingly and made [his]653-the maire eyes sparkle with pleasure , for [he]653-the maire overheard these things ; so [he]653-the maire went on in the same fertile and brilliant way . “ Now , then , [we]2428-we will consider what the term responsibility means , and how it affects the case in point . Responsibility makes [a man]2329-a man responsible for only those things for which [he]2329-a man is properly responsible”—and[652-her scowling father] [he]652-her scowling father waved [his]652-her scowling father spoon around in a wide sweep to indicate the comprehensive nature of that class of responsibilities which render [people responsible]661-people responsible , and [several]662-several exclaimed , admiringly , “ [He]652-her scowling father is right!—he has put that whole tangled thing into a nutshell — it is wonderful ! ”[662-several] After a little pause to give the interest opportunity to gather and grow , [he]652-her scowling father went on : “ Very good . Let [us]2428-we suppose the case of a pair of tongs that falls upon [a man]2329-a man ’s foot , causing a cruel hurt . Will [you]2431-you claim that the tongs are punishable for that ? The question is answered ; [I]652-her scowling father see by [your]2431-you faces that [you]2431-you would call such a claim absurd . Now , why is it absurd ? It is absurd because , there being no reasoning faculty — that is to say , no faculty of personal command — in a pair of tongs , personal responsibility for the acts of the tongs is wholly absent from the tongs ; and , therefore , responsibility being absent , punishment can not ensue . Am [I]652-her scowling father right ? ”[652-her scowling father] A hearty burst of applause was [his]652-her scowling father answer . “ Now , then , [we]2428-we arrive at [a man]2329-a man ’s stomach . Consider how exactly , how marvelously , indeed , its situation corresponds to that of a pair of tongs . Listen — and take careful note , [I]652-her scowling father beg [you]2431-you . Can [a man]2329-a man ’s stomach plan a murder ? No . Can it plan a theft ? No . Can it plan an incendiary fire ? No . Now answer [me]652-her scowling father — can a pair of tongs ? ”[652-her scowling father] ( There were admiring shouts of “ No ! ”[652-her scowling father] and “ The cases are just exact ! ”[652-her scowling father] and “ Do n’t [he]652-her scowling father do it splendid ! ”[652-her scowling father] ) “ Now , then , [friends]2434-friends and [neighbors]2435-neighbors , a stomach which can not plan a crime can not be a principal in the commission of it — that is plain , as [you]2431-you see . The matter is narrowed down by that much ; [we]2428-we will narrow it further . Can a stomach , of its own motion , assist at a crime ? The answer is no , because command is absent , the reasoning faculty is absent , volition is absent — as in the case of the tongs . [We]2428-we perceive now , do [we]2428-we not , that the stomach is totally irresponsible for crimes committed , either in whole or in part , by it ? ”[652-her scowling father] [He]652-her scowling father got a rousing cheer for response . “ Then what do [we]2428-we arrive at as [our]2428-we verdict ? Clearly this : that there is no such thing in [this world]345-this world as a guilty stomach ; that in the body of [the veriest rascal]2437-the veriest rascal resides a pure and innocent stomach ; that , whatever it ’s owner may do , it at least should be sacred in [our]2428-we eyes ; and that while [God]140-god gives [us]2428-we minds to think just and charitable and honorable thoughts , it should be , and is , [our]2428-we privilege , as well as [our]2428-we duty , not only to feed the hungry stomach that resides in [a rascal]2409-a rascal , having pity for its sorrow and its need , but to do it gladly , gratefully , in recognition of its sturdy and loyal maintenance of its purity and innocence in the midst of temptation and in company so repugnant to its better feelings . [I]652-her scowling father am done . ”[652-her scowling father] Well , [you]663-you never saw such an effect ! [They]664-they rose — [the whole house]665-the whole house rose — an clapped , and cheered , and praised [him]652-her scowling father to the skies ; and one after another , still clapping and shouting , [they]664-they crowded forward , some with moisture in [their]664-they eyes , and wrung [his]652-her scowling father hands , and said such glorious things to [him]652-her scowling father that [he]652-her scowling father was clear overcome with pride and happiness , and could n’t say a word , for [his]652-her scowling father voice would have broken , sure . It was splendid to see ; and [everybody]464-everybody said [he]652-her scowling father had never come up to that speech in [his]652-her scowling father life before , and never could do it again . Eloquence is a power , there is no question of that . Even [old Jacques d’Arc]130-jacques was carried away , for once in [his]130-jacques life , and shouted out : “ It ’s all right , [Joan]110-joan — give [him]648-the man the porridge ! ”[130-jacques] [She]667-she was embarrassed , and did not seem to know what to say , and so did n’t say anything . It was because [she]667-she had given [the man]648-the man the porridge long ago and [he]648-the man had already eaten it all up . When [she]667-she was asked why [she]667-she had not waited until a decision was arrived at , [she]667-she said [the man]648-the man ’s stomach was very hungry , and it would not have been wise to wait , since [she]667-she could not tell what the decision would be . Now that was a good and thoughtful idea for [a child]327-a child . [The man]648-the man was not [a rascal at all]672-a rascal at all . [He]648-the man was [a very good fellow]673-a very good fellow , only [he]648-the man was out of luck , and surely that was no crime at that time in [France]4-france . Now that [his]648-the man stomach was proved to be innocent , it was allowed to make itself at [home]377-home ; and as soon as it was well filled and needed nothing more , [the man]648-the man unwound [his]648-the man tongue and turned it loose , and it was really a noble one to go . [He]648-the man had been in the wars for years , and the things [he]648-the man told and the way [he]648-the man told [them]676-them fired [everybody]464-everybody ’s patriotism away up high , and set all hearts to thumping and all pulses to leaping ; then , before [anybody]563-anybody rightly knew how the change was made , [he]648-the man was leading [us]679-we a sublime march through [the ancient glories of [France]4-france]680-the ancient glories of france , and in fancy [we]679-we saw the titanic forms of [the twelve paladins rise out of the mists of the past]681-the twelve paladins rise out of the mists of the past and face [their]681-the twelve paladins rise out of the mists of the past fate ; [we]679-we heard the tread of [the innumerable hosts sweeping down to shut them in]682-the innumerable hosts sweeping down to shut them in ; [we]679-we saw this human tide flow and ebb , ebb and flow , and waste away before [that little band of heroes]683-that little band of heroes ; [we]679-we saw each detail pass before [us]679-we of that most stupendous , most disastrous , yet most adored and glorious day in French legendary history ; here and there and yonder , across [that vast field of]684-that vast field of [the dead and dying]685-the dead and dying , [we]679-we saw this and that and [the other paladin]686-the other paladin dealing [his]686-the other paladin prodigious blows with weary arm and failing strength , and one by one [we]679-we saw [them]687-them fall , till [only one]688-only one remained — [he]686-the other paladin that was without [peer]689-peer , [he]686-the other paladin [whose name gives name to the Song of Songs]690-whose name gives name to the song of songs , the song which [no Frenchman]691-no frenchman can hear and keep [his]691-no frenchman feelings down and [his]691-no frenchman pride of country cool ; then , grandest and pitifulest scene of all , [we]679-we saw [his]686-the other paladin own pathetic death ; and [our]679-we stillness , as [we]679-we sat with parted lips and breathless , hanging upon [this man]692-this man ’s words , gave [us]679-we a sense of the awful stillness that reigned in that field of slaughter when [that last surviving soul]693-that last surviving soul had passed . And now , in this solemn hush , [the stranger]647-the stranger gave [Joan]110-joan a pat or two on the head and said : “ [Little maid]2439-little maid — whom God keep!—you have brought [me]647-the stranger from death to life this night ; now listen : here is [your]110-joan reward , ”[647-the stranger] and at that supreme time for such a heart - melting , soul - rousing surprise , without another word [he]647-the stranger lifted up the most noble and pathetic voice that was ever heard , and began to pour out the great Song of [Roland]146-roland ! Think of that , with [a French audience]695-a french audience all stirred up and ready . Oh , where was [your]696-your spoken eloquence now ! what was it to this ! How fine [he]647-the stranger looked , how stately , how inspired , as [he]647-the stranger stood there with that mighty chant welling from [his]647-the stranger lips and [his]647-the stranger heart , [his]647-the stranger whole body transfigured , and [his]647-the stranger rags along with it .
